body_html:
This is unrelated to Sierra. It's a flaw in the design of contrib/makefile. What most likely happened is you tried out the Makefile build system. Then you decided to go back to using Bazel. Because bazel fetch //tensorflow/... crawled the protobuf build files in the downloads directory left over by the makefile, and those BUILD files defined external dependencies we don't specify, things didn't work.

To work around this issue, rm -rf tensorflow/contrib/makefile/downloads before running ./configure. The download_dependencies.sh script can always recreate that directory as needed.

I'm not sure if this is a bug we can fix, without a nontrivial redesigning contrib/makefile. I want to thank you for bringing this to our attention. But I'm leaning towards closing this issue for now. Although @martinwicke or @gunan may re-open it if they disagree.

body:
This is unrelated to Sierra. It's a flaw in the design of contrib/makefile. What most likely happened is you tried out the Makefile build system. Then you decided to go back to using Bazel. Because `bazel fetch //tensorflow/...` crawled the protobuf build files in the downloads directory left over by the makefile, and those BUILD files defined external dependencies we don't specify, things didn't work.

To work around this issue, `rm -rf tensorflow/contrib/makefile/downloads` before running `./configure`. The download_dependencies.sh script can always recreate that directory as needed.

I'm not sure if this is a bug we can fix, without a nontrivial redesigning contrib/makefile. I want to thank you for bringing this to our attention. But I'm leaning towards closing this issue for now. Although @martinwicke or @gunan may re-open it if they disagree.
